item.title: Statistical Mechanics and the Tutte Polynomial
item.description:
Title: Statistical Mechanics and the Tutte Polynomial

Speaker: Nathan Hayford

Date/Time: Friday, January 28th, 2:00 pm

Abstract: The Tutte polynomial is a well-known graph invariant, from which many important graph-theoretic properties can be read off. We discuss the equivalence of this polynomial to an important model in statistical physics: the q-Potts model, which is a generalization of the simplistic model of a magnet (the Ising model). We use this equivalence to develop the well-known high-temperature expansion of the Potts mode. Furthermore, we discuss what we can learn about graph theory from statistical mechanics, and vice versa.

item.title: Covid-19 Spreading: An Eigenvalue Viewpoint
item.description:
Title: Covid-19 Spreading: An Eigenvalue Viewpoint

Speaker: Haowei (Alice) Chen

Date/Time: Friday, October 29th, 2:00pm

Abstract: How will a virus propagate? How long does it take to disinfect given infection rate and virus death rate? What is the best node to immunize? We answer these questions by developing a nonlinear dynamical system that models viral propagation in any arbitrary network and also a general epidemic threshold is proposed: the inverse of the largest eigenvalue of the adjacency matrix.

item.title: Prodsimplicial and p-path complexes on directed graphs
item.description:
Title: Prodsimplicial and p-path complexes on directed graphs

Speaker: Lina Fajardo Gomez

Date/Time: Wednesday, January 20th, 2020

Abstract: At face value, a graph is a simplicial complex that only has faces of dimension 0 (vertices) and 1 (edges). However, given appropriate definitions, higher dimensional cells can emerge. We present two such definitions, prodsimplicial complexes and p-path complexes, and compare in examples the homology groups obtained for different graphs.

Zoom Link: https://zoom.us/j/96345929862

item.title: Introduction to Matroids
item.description:
Title: Introduction to matroids

Speaker: Lina Fajardo Gomez

Date: Thursday, July 30th

Time: 2:00pm

Abstract: Matroids are mathematical objects that abstract the notion of linearly independent sets. They have applications in many areas of mathematics, ranging from combinatorics to field theory. In this talk I will give an overview of matroids, why they are studied and why I in particular took an interest in them.

Link to Zoom meeting: https://zoom.us/j/93617336971

Video: Google Drive.

Slides: Google Drive.
